# Effects of Land Use in Census Places on Pollinator Diversity

## Literature review

### Introduction
The goal of this paper is to assess the effects of human land use in Oregon's Cities and Census designated places on local pollinator diversity.
The effects of land use on pollinator diversity has been widely studied across different contexts around the world. In a large-scale review of 
studies researchers have found positive correlations between land use intensity and reductions in alpha-diversity [@tsang_land_2025]. Another 
review also saw a positive correlation between land use intensity and overall reductions in pollinator diversity, though their results
found little correlation between land use type and pollinator diversity [@millard_global_2021].

Other studies have looked at the effect of land use on the biodiversity of other flora and fauna, with results being generally similar to those
that assessed pollinators only [@lisboa_assessing_2022; @newbold_global_2020; @semenchuk_relative_2022]. Others have found more mixed results
across different contexts, seeing more biodiversity loss in certain areas or in some animal species over others [@newbold_global_2020;
@jernakoff_effects_2023; @cabernard_biodiversity_2024]. These other studies show that generalizing the effects of land use on other animal species
to animal biodiversity as a whole could be a mistake and lead to different results than those seen among pollinators specifically.

The data that can answer this question exists in the form of the annual surveys carried out by the National Land Cover Database (NLCD). These surveys
are formatted as large raster files that show the land cover of the United States. This data can be obtained as a raster of the whole United States
through the Multi-Resolution Land Characteristics Consortium (MRLC) or can be narrowed to specific areas of the country using the United States
Geological Survey's EarthExplorer tool.

### Purpose
The data I used to test my hypotheses comes from the Oregon Bee Atlas (OBA) for bee diversity, and the National Historical Geographic Information
System (NHGIS). The NHGIS gathered data from the NLCD and summarized it across US census places. The data that I ultimately used is the 2022 census 
place dataset as out of those available from the NHGIS this one was the most fine-grained, detailed dataset to pair with the OBA dataset. I was limited
by my lack of knowledge in using spatial data earlier in the course of making this project, otherwise I would have used the more fine-grained data 
available through the MRLC. Given this lack of knowledge and the limited time remaining since gaining it, I have used data that is less detailed but 
that I have found easier to work with.

### Hypotheses
I predict that census places with more land use intensity will have lower levels of pollinator diversity because that would be in line with other
research on this problem. For this project the null hypothesis will be that there is no difference in pollinator diversity between areas with lower
and higher land use. The alternative hypothesis will be the before mentioned hypothesis, that areas with higher land use will have lower biodiversity.

## Datasets
- NHGIS Land Cover Summary (https://www.nhgis.org/environmental-summaries): Collected by the NLCD, summarized by the NHGIS into different census 
categories (counties, census tracts, places, county subdivisions).
- OBA data: I plan to transform the OBA data through subsetting the data to combine with the land use dataset. Since the OBA data is individual
collection records across various census places, this data will have to be transformed such that the biodiversity of each census place in the land
use data is found in the OBA data.

## Workflow Plan
1) Cleaning & validation: As far as I know the land use data will not need to be cleaned in any way but if any of the places in the land use data
are not present in the OBA data then those will need to be removed. I am unsure about whether the OBA data will need to be cleaned but if it does
then that will be shown in the "clean_data" file in the analysis folder and mentioned in the paper.

2) Aggregations/derivations: The land use data will need to be adjusted so that city and place names are shown rather than FIPS codes. This can be
done by comparing the codes to those in the list of FIPS codes for Oregon census places. This list of names is found in the data folder and can be
found on the Census' website ([link](https://www.census.gov/library/reference/code-lists/ansi.html)). The adjustments for the OBA data is mentioned 
in the "Datasets" section.

3) Functions/loops (inputs â†’ outputs): I will need to write a function for computing diversity once I decide how I will measure diversity. I
can't think of any loops I will have to write to complete the project.

4) Statistical test + programmatic implementation: For testing the hypothesis I will use bootstrapping to draw random samples from the data and use
a linear regression to test the relationship between land use and biodiversity. This will require that I create some continuous measure of land use.
Since the data I have presents land use in proportions, I will be able to use this for designing my measure of land use.

5) Planned visualizations/tables: I plan to visualize the relationship between the two variables directly, as well as a map of oregon places and 
their respective measurements of biodiversity.

6) Risks & mitigations: There is a risk in combining the OBA data into census places as this may not get all of the detail in the data. I plan to
mitigate this by analyzing the data within each place and making assessments around how well the data is being captured by grouping it this way.
If outliers are of major concern then handling those will be addressed in the paper.
